text.31_Chapter, 4_Verse, 1_Comment: (2) NO [alt.: TO HIM].  In other words, not to another.
text.25_Chapter, 11_Verse, 0_Comment: [IN THE THIRD YEAR,] THE YEAR OF THE TITHE.  The tithe for the poor.
text.30_Chapter, 18_Verse, 1_Comment: (2) THIS [POEM]. Parashat Ha'azinu, which bears witness against them regarding destruction when they will transgress the commandments, and they will understand that it is because of their sins that they have been punished.
text.32_Chapter, 1_Verse, 2_Comment: (3) FROM SE'IR and Paran.  How?  AND CAME from among THE MYRIADS OF HOLY BEINGS.  From all four sides of Mt. Sinai came the light and the angels, by way of Se'ir and Paran until it reached Sinai and FROM HIS RIGHT HAND He gave them religious law [dat] from within the fire [eish], as He spoke to Israel, as it is written (Deut. 4:33), "Has any people heard the voice of a god speaking out of a fire, as you have, and survived?"  And we also find in Psalms (68:18), "God’s chariots are myriads upon myriads, thousands upon thousands; the Lord is among them as in Sinai in holiness."   And in Habakkuk (3:3), "God is coming from Teman, The Holy One from Mount Paran.Selah. His majesty covers the skies."  And about D'vorah it is written (Jud. 5:4), "O LORD, when You came forth from Seir, Advanced from the country of Edom."  ...
text.11_Chapter, 1_Verse, 0_Comment: (1) WHERE THEY WORSHIPPED THEIR GODS, THE NATIONS THAT YOU ARE DISPLACING. [i.e., placing the phrases of the clause in a more natural order.]
text.25_Chapter, 4_Verse, 0_Comment: MY FATHER WAS A FUGITIVE ARAMEAN.   My father Avraham was an Aramean, wandering and exiled from the land of Aram, as it is written (Gen. 12:1), "Get yourself out from your land," and as it is written (Gen. 20:13), "So when God made me wander from my father’s house ...."  The expressions oved and to'eh are one and the same, referring to a person who is exiled, as it is written (Ps. 119:176), "I have strayed like a lost sheep; search for Your servant" [and] (Jer. 50:6), "My people were lost sheep: their shepherds led them astray."   In other words, our ancestors came from a foreign land to this land and it was the Holy One, blessed be He, Who gave it to us.
text.6_Chapter, 11_Verse, 0_Comment: THE LORD ... WILL MAINTAIN FOR YOU.  Because for a fit generation, He maintains the promise of faith with the ancestors, and if you do not keep the commandments, He will not maintain for you, but for a different generation.
text.16_Chapter, 17_Verse, 0_Comment: (1) MISHNEH TORAH.  My grandfather explained it in [his commentary on] Chronicles [alt.:  according to the words of the Sages] as two Torah scrolls.  Also the Targum has "patshegen." But it [mishneh] is not from the same root as v'shinantam (Deut 6:7).
text.31_Chapter, 4_Verse, 2_Comment: (3) HIS CHILDREN -- THEIR BLEMISH [BANAV MUMAM].  "Their blemish" is a repetition of "Israel has been base" -- the children of the Holy One, blessed be He, made this blemish on themselves, as it is written (Lev. 22:25), "for they are mutilated, they have a defect."
text.31_Chapter, 2_Verse, 0_Comment: WHEN [KI] I CALL THE NAME OF ADONAI.  When I recount to you the mighty deeds that the Holy One, blessed be He, performed for you, and the benefits that He bestowed on you, and that He is righteous in what He does for you, then you also -- ACCORD GREATNESS TO OUR GOD -- acknowledge the truth.
text.31_Chapter, 3_Verse, 0_Comment: THE ROCK!—HIS DEEDS ARE PERFECT.   This poem serves as a witness.  Therefore, the poem speaks about after retribution will come to Israel for their sins:  "The Rock!  His deeds are perfect" in all of the retribution that He has brought upon you.
text.0_Chapter, 0_Verse, 1_Comment: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE JORDAN.  On which "other side of the Jordan"?
text.0_Chapter, 0_Verse, 2_Comment: IN THE WILDERNESS.  On that "other side of the Jordan" that is on the side of the wilderness where Israel was for 40 years, which is called the "other side of the Jordan" for the residents of the Land of Israel, and not the "other side of the Jordan" that is the Land of Israel side, for it is also called the "other side of the Jordan" for those who are going through the wilderness where Israel was.
text.6_Chapter, 22_Verse, 0_Comment: MAKING A GREAT NOISE [THROWING THEM INTO  UTTER PANIC].  "V'hamam" must be [structurally] like "v'savav Beit El" (I Sam. 7:16), "shamam" from "sh'mamah" (desolation): "On Mt. Zion, which is shamem," and in the category of doubles [a three-letter root with the second and third letters the same], and it means that He raised His voice to make a great noise in the war to the extent of destroying them.  And if the meaning of the final mem were like "otam" ["them"] [i.e., a pronominal object suffix], it should have written "v'hamamam."  However, from the root heh-mem-heh, [the basis of] "yehemeh libi" (Jer. 48:36 [reversed]), one could say "v'hamam," [i.e.,] "v'hamah otam," as from "asah" [he made], [we derive] "otz'bi asam" (Isa. 48:5 -- "my idol made them"), and from "When Ya'akov saw [ra'ah]" (Gen. 29:10) [we derive] "And Ya'kov said when he saw them (ra'am)" (Gen. 32:3) -- "ra'ah otam."  And "hamam" from the root h-m-h would be explained "hamah otam."  And if you say that this [the actual word in our verse] should also be interpreted as "hamah otam," you can't say that, because the word himyon [making a loud noise] is intransitive:  "My mind yehemeh like a harp" (Jer. 48:36, modified) -- of its own.  If the action was done to something else [i.e., if it were a transitive verb], one would have to make it a stronger conjugation [a pi'el]: v'himem.  For example, "my body kalah [failed]" (Ps. 73:26) -- by itself; "my enemies kilam [has consumed them]" (Lam. 2:22) -- others, or "the LORD kilah [exhausted] his anger" (Lam. 4:11). [Another example:] "yishneh [debased, changed] is the finest gold" (Lam. 4:1) -- by itself, thus the soft conjugation [a kal]; but [done] to others it would say "v'shinah [changed] his prison garments" (II Kings 25:29) or "vay'shaneha [he treated her differently] and her maids" (Esth. 2:9).
text.28_Chapter, 17_Verse, 0_Comment: (1) TO THE UTTER RUIN OF MOIST.  Who sins even out of satiety.
text.15_Chapter, 20_Verse, 0_Comment: BESIDE THE ALTAR.  Because that is where people usually made them, as it is written in connection with Gid'on (Jud. 6:25), "cut down the sacred post which is beside it [the altar]"; [and] (Jer. 17:2) "While their children remember Their altars and sacred posts, By verdant trees."
text.10_Chapter, 29_Verse, 0_Comment: AHAREI DERECH.  These are like two [words with the trop sign] pashta.  However, since the accent in "derech" is on the first syllable, it [the pashta] becomes a shofar mahpach [i.e., a y'tiv].
text.31_Chapter, 9_Verse, 1_Comment: (2) HE ENGIRDED THEM.  With His angels, who guarded them, and thus established the poet (a "magen" piyyut for Rosh Hashana day 2): "may Your angel camp round about us."  And it is not according to one who explains it as a surrounding by clouds, as, according to the straightforward sense, there was no cloud except the pillar of cloud in front of them, as it is written (Ex. 13:21), "The LORD went before them in a pillar of cloud by day, to guide them along the way."  And further, the "yitz'ren'hu" ("He watched over him") duplicates [by parallelism] "y'sov'venhu."
text.26_Chapter, 14_Verse, 0_Comment: AND SETS IT UP IN SECRET.  The curses number 12, corresponding to the 12 tribes, and they are all sins that are typically committed in private, as I will explain about each of them.  This [setting up an idol "in secret"] is one of two that are typically committed either publicly or privately -- they are idolatry and murder.  And that is why it specifies about each of these "in secret."  For regarding sins committed publicly, they did not come to curse, because the court will punish him for sins committed openly, as it says at the end of all the curses (Deut. 29:28):  "Concealed acts concern Adonai our God" -- He will exact vengeance for sins committed in private, for after all, they were cursed in the name of the Holy One blessed be He -- "but with overt acts, it is for us and our children ever to apply all the provisions of this Teaching" -- lashes, stoning, burning, the sword, and strangulation....
text.15_Chapter, 21_Verse, 0_Comment: DO NOT ERECT FOR YOURSELF A MATZEIVAH.  For heaven [i.e., for God], to butn sacrifices on it during the periods when the bamot (high places) were prohibited, since you wll have a fixed altar after the apportionment [of the Land], as it is written (Deut. 12:8), "You shall not act at all as we now act here, etc.," offering sacrifices in any place at all, and as it is written in Chronicles (II, 20:33), "However, the shrines did not cease", and it explains there that the were sacrificing to Adonai only.
text.32_Chapter, 1_Verse, 0_Comment: (1) ADONAI CAME FROM SE'IR.  He appeared to Israeland gave them His Torah.
text.32_Chapter, 0_Verse, 1_Comment: AND THIS IS THE BLESSING.  (One) [After] the rebuke of Ha'azinu, he reversed and blessed Israel before ascending the mountain to die there; in other words, this is the poem, "And this is the blessing."
text.32_Chapter, 0_Verse, 0_Comment: AND THIS IS THE BLESSING.  This refers to what is above (Deut. 31:30 - 32:1), " Then Moses recited the words of this poem to the very end, in the hearing of the whole congregation of Israel.  Give ear, O heavens, etc."
text.8_Chapter, 24_Verse, 0_Comment: ... Moshe said to them, "Prayer will not be efficacious for you in the Land of Israel; for currently, atonement is effected for you so that His name will not be desecrated, and that is what I have prayed: 'Give thought to Your servants, etc.  Else the country from which You freed us will say, "It was because Adonai was powerless to bring them."'"  Thus you were not liable for the death penalty because of it.  However, after He kills 31 kings and gives you the Land as an inheritance, then He will expel you and exile you from the Land, for there will not be in that any desecration of the name, saying to the nations, "Because Adonai was powerless"; rather, the nations will say, "Israel sinned against Him." ....
text.7_Chapter, 19_Verse, 0_Comment: BECAUSE YOU DID NOT HEED.  This is the conclusion of the entire beginning of the parasha.  V'HAYAH EKEV TISH'M'UN [If you do obey], you will come to own the land; V'EKEV LO TISH'M'UN [Because you did not heed], you shall perish from it.
text.25_Chapter, 9_Verse, 0_Comment: WHEREFORE I NOW BRING THE FIRST FRUITS OF THE SOIL WHICH YOU.  For it is not through my own effort that this is accomplished, but rather through Your lovingkindness that I have obtained it.  And it was in this way that Yehoshua reproved Israel (Josh 24:2): "In olden times, your forefathers lived beyond the Euphrates: Terah" until I brought them from there and gave them the land of Canaan.
text.28_Chapter, 17_Verse, 1_Comment: (2) THE DRY.  Responding to his appetite, for he is not as evil as the one who acts in spite, out of satiety.
text.31_Chapter, 1_Verse, 0_Comment: MAY [MY DISCOURSE] COME DOWN AS THE RAIN.  If you accept My words of rebuke, they will benefit you as does the rain.
text.31_Chapter, 4_Verse, 0_Comment: (1) HE HAS BEEN BASE TO HIM.  Israel has been base to itself, as it is written (Hos. 13:9), "You harmed yourself, Israel! You had no help but Me"  -- he caused destruction to himself.
text.5_Chapter, 6_Verse, 0_Comment: V'SHINANTAM.  An expression of sharpening -- to explain them well, as in (Ps. 64:4), "They sharpened their tongues like swords."
text.31_Chapter, 9_Verse, 0_Comment: (1) YIMTZA'EIHU.  As in (Num. 11:22), "to suffice them."  The Holy One blessed be He was "at hand" for them (Jer. 29:14); the Holy One blessed be He supplied them.
text.6_Chapter, 13_Verse, 0_Comment: AKAR.  Both vowels are kamatz.  It is similar to the following:  from hacham it says, "ishah hachama"(II Sam. 14:2); from shafal, "sh'fala einenah" (Lev. 13:21).  Similarly, from "akar" "akarah."  I have found the word [vocalized] this way in all of the texts from Spain.
text.32_Chapter, 1_Verse, 3_Comment: (4) HE APPEARED FROM MT. PARAN.  He shone from Mt. Paran.
text.31_Chapter, 3_Verse, 1_Comment: TRUE AND UPRIGHT IS HE.  As it proceeds to explain, that He has benefitted them in various ways, but they -- (v.15) "Yeshurun grew fat ... he forsook the God Who made him."
text.0_Chapter, 0_Verse, 0_Comment: THESE ARE THE WORDS. According to its straightforward sense, all of the items mentioned in this verse are place names, as we find is common for verses to provide identification after identification as to which it wants to explain where they are.  As in Lech L'cha (Gen. 12:8):  "east of Bethel and pitched his tent, with Bethel on the west and Ai on the east."  [In Parashat B'shalah:] (Ex. 14:2)  "turn back and encamp before Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea, before Baal-zephon."  In the book of Judges (21:19):  "The annual feast of the LORD is now being held at Shiloh.  (It lies north of Bethel, east of the highway that runs from Bethel to Shechem, and south of Lebonah.)"  And all the more necessary it is to specify the locations where the mitzvot were spoken, as it is written (Lev. 25:1) "The LORD spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai"; (Ex. 12:1-2) "in the land of Egypt: This month shall mark for you"; (Num. 33:50) "In the steppes of Moab."  Likewise here, it makes identification after identification.  And it similarly states and repeats and reiterates this matter when Moshe comes to elaborate the commandments (Deut. 4:45-46):  "these are the decrees, laws, and rules that Moses addressed ... beyond the Jordan, in the valley at Beth-peor, in the land of King Sihon of the Amorites."  [And (Deut. 1:5) "On the other side of the Jordan, in the land of Moab,] Moses undertook [to expound this Teaching.]
text.31_Chapter, 9_Verse, 2_Comment: (3) K'ISHON EINO.  The Holy One blessed be He protects Israel as the ishon protects its eye.  It is the flesh that folds over the eye (the eyelid), which is called "palpayra."  And because it covers the eye and darkens it, it is called "ishon," as in, "Guard me like the apple of Your eye" (as the ishon does to the bat ayin).  [It is the bat ayin that is the pupil], as (Zec. 2:12) "touches the pupil of his own eye."  It is what they call "fronila," with which one sees.
text.28_Chapter, 8_Verse, 0_Comment: (1) YOU STAND THIS DAY, ALL OF YOU. as we know from verse 1: "Moses summoned all Israel, etc."
text.15_Chapter, 20_Verse, 1_Comment: DO NOT PLANT FOR YOURSELF AN ASHERAH.  No tree at all, so that you will not come to worship it, as is the custom among idolaters.
text.11_Chapter, 3_Verse, 0_Comment: DO NOT DO THUS, to sacrifice TO THE LORD in every place [as opposed to only in the central shrine].
text.11_Chapter, 7_Verse, 0_Comment: EACH PERSON AS HE PLEASES.  Every place where we camp in the  wilderness we sacrifice, in a Tabernacle that is moved from place to place.
text.31_Chapter, 7_Verse, 1_Comment: (2) WHEN HE SET THE DIVISIONS OF HUMANITY. After the death of Noah, and in the days of Avraham, for it is written there (Gen. 10:5), "From there [in the verse, "these"] the maritime nations branched out ... each with its language." And you will find there that HE FIXED [hitziv; in the verse, "yatziv"] THE BOUNDARIES OF PEOPLES -- the sons of C'na'an were 12, corresponding to the number of Ya'akov's sons, who were 12. For you will find (see Gen. 10:15-18) that C'na'an and his 11 sons totaled 12, and it is written there (Gen. 10:19), "And the border of the Canaanite was from Tzidon, etc.," since all of this was for Israel, but it does not mention a border for any other descendant of Noah. I also found in a midrash as I have explained: IN RELATION TO ISRAEL’S NUMBERS. That C'na'an and his sons were so -- they were 12.
text.15_Chapter, 17_Verse, 0_Comment: JUDGES AND OFFICERS.  The judges command the officers to subdue those who refuse [to obey] the judges.
text.32_Chapter, 2_Verse, 0_Comment: LOVER, INDEED, OF PEOPLES.  Also the nations of the world, such as the erev rav and [those] among the nations who converted and came to accept the Torah with Israel.  Them also the Holy One, blessed be He, loved, and He accepted them and resided over them, as it is written in the Psalm (68:2), "God will arise, His enemies shall be scattered," and as it is written (ib. v.18), "God’s chariots [... the Lord is among them as in Sinai in holiness.]"
text.31_Chapter, 7_Verse, 0_Comment: (1) B'HAN'HIL ELYON GOYIM [WHEN THE MOST HIGH CAUSED THE NATIONS TO INHERIT]. When He gave them landholdings [nahalot].
text.30_Chapter, 18_Verse, 0_Comment: (1) POEM [HASHIRAH]. An ordering of words is called a "shirah."
text.31_Chapter, 0_Verse, 0_Comment: LISTEN, HEAVENS.  To exact retribution against Israel if they sin, as it is written (Deut. 11:17), "He will shut up the skies, etc."
